awd_titl_txt: Estimation of High Dimensional Matrices of Low Effective Rank with Applications to Structural Copula Models
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Modeling high dimensional data and evaluating their variability presents increasing challenges  in many scientific disciplines.  For instance, such challenges occur in modeling network data in genetics and molecular biology; high dimensional portfolios in economics; and samples of curves in psychology, public health, transportation and urban planning. Substantially better solutions can be provided whenever the data is generated by a model with low dimensional structure.
This grant investigated appropriate notions of effective dimension in a number of related, but different, problems: 
(a) the formulation of the relevant notion of effective rank for covariance matrices and operators;  
(b) the problem of estimating covariance matrices over classes of high dimensional models of reduced effective rank, especially in functional data settings;
(c) the  problem of estimating the correlation matrix of an elliptical copula, and its connections with (a) and (b).   


The intellectual merits of the proposed activity.
The central goals were
(a)  To provide sharp finite sample bounds, in both Frobenius and operator norms, on the accuracy of the sample covariance estimator of high dimensional covariance matrices;
(b)  To extend these results to functional data and characterize classes of covariance operators of reduced effective rank;
(c) To study factor models of high dimensional correlation matrices of elliptical copulas. 
These goals were addressed in a series of papers. A new sparse estimator of the covariance matrix for high-dimensional models in which the variables have a known ordering was introduced.  This estimator is the solution to a convex optimization problem and can be computed by an efficient algorithm. It can equivalently be expressed as an estimator which tapers the sample covariance matrix by a Toeplitz, sparsely-banded, data-adaptive matrix. As a result of this adaptivity, the estimator enjoys theoretical optimality properties (in operator and Frobenius norms) not attained by previous banding or tapered estimators. The new method compared favorably with all existing methods, in terms of accuracy and speed. It also provided an improved performance of classifying sound recordings.Another work provided a unified analysis of the properties of the sample covariance matrix  over the class of population covariance matrices of reduced effective rank. Sharp minimax rates on the operator and Frobenius norm of the difference of  the  difference between the sample and population covariance matrices as a function of  the reduced rank and  the operator norm of the population matrix. With guidelines offered by the optimal rates, classes of matrices of reduced effective rank over which the sample covariance matrix is an accurate estimator can be described. These results and analysis are specialized to population covariance matrices with polynomially decaying spectra, with an application to functional data analysis.

While the above works address goals (a) and (b), goal (c) was addressed in a study of adaptive estimation of  the elliptical copula correlation matrix. In this context, the correlations are connected to Kendall’s tau through a sine function transformation. A natural estimate is therefore the plug-in estimator with Kendall’s tau statistic. A sharp bound on the operator norm of  the difference between the estimate and its target is given. The bound served to scale the penalty term in a proposed penalized least squares procedure that fits a low-rank matrix plus a diagonal matrix to the plug-in estimate using a nuclear norm penalty on the low-rank matrix. Again, the convex formulation allowed for an implementable, fully data-driven, method, and sharp finite sample bounds were derived for the estimator. Finally, binary classification of two distributions with the same Gaussian copula in high dimensions was studied. An estimation procedure was developed that takes advantage of the potential sparsity as well as the low noise condition in the problem.  

Additional results for variable clustering and weak convergence of empirical copula processes were obtained.

All these works were done by the PIs in collaboration with colleagues and students from Cornell (statistics and computational biology), Brown (biostatistics), Paris Sud (mathematics), Paris ENSAE (economics), Florida Atlantic University (mathematics). 

 

 


The broader impacts of the proposed activity.
The results were reported in leading statistical journals and various international conferences. In particular, both principal investigators were program leaders for the 2013-2014 SAMSI program on High Dimensional Models with Low Dimensional Structures.

Free software that implements the developed  methodology is available on the web in a readily implementable form.

The results of this project are incorporated into MATH 7740, a Statistical Learning class at Cornell.

Goal (c) was part of  Yue Zhao's PhD thesis under supervision of the PI.
